isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - DETROIT DIESEL SERIES 60 - 1992 - 1993 - TROUBLESHOOTING - THROTTLE POSITION SENSOR (TPS)

svcprocinfo.para: Review the circuit diagram and inspect the TPS circuits and connectors as outlined in paragraph BEFORE TROUBLESHOOTING.

svcsubproc.title: Testing Throttle Position Sensor (TPS) Circuits
svcsubproc.para: This procedure tests the Throttle Position Sensor circuits for short circuits (HIGH and LOW) and for circuit continuity. This procedure must be performed before performing Testing Throttle Position Sensor (TPS) Assembly.

svcsubproc.title: Testing Throttle Position Sensor Circuits
svcsubproc.para: It is important to test the Throttle Position Sensor circuits for short circuits (HIGH and LOW) and for circuit continuity before performing Testing Throttle Position Sensor (TPS) Assembly.

svcsubproc.title: Testing Throttle Position Sensor (TPS) Assembly
svcsubproc.para: This test requires the use of the Pro Link EST to identify proper pedal operation. The Pro Link EST identifies the number of counts, which are sent to the ECM for interpretation of throttle position. Refer to the Pro Link manual for this operation. Also refer to paragraph Throttle Position Sensor for a complete discussion on counts.

TPS output of 0 to 19 counts will cause an "out of range LOW" fault code, while output of 235 to 256 counts will cause an "out of range HIGH" fault code to be set. It is important to note that TPS circuit defects can cause the same codes as a defective pedal, so the circuits must be checked before checking the pedal assembly.

note.para: Perform Testing Throttle Position Sensor Circuits before performing this test.
